description.en: The course will in each different year examine a particular work in moral philosophy that is especially significant in the history of moral philosophy and that continues to be relevant for contemporary debates, whether in normative ethics, metaethics, applied ethics, etc.
description.et: Kursuse käigus vaadeldakse igal aastal üht moraalifilosoofia ajaloos eriliselt tähenduslikku teksti, mis püsib olulisena ka tänapäeva normatiivse eetika, metaeetika ja rakenduseetika alastes debattides.

objectives.en: 1. To offer a systematic introduction to a significant text in moral philosophy.
objectives.et: * tutvustada tudengitele süstemaatiliselt üht moraalifilosoofia olulist teksti,

objectives.en: 2. To show the importance of the text both in the author's context and for contemporary debates in ethics.
objectives.et: * näidata selle teksti tähtsust nii autori vaadete kui tänapäeva moraalifilosoofiliste debattide kontekstis,

objectives.en: 3. To reconstruct and assess the plausibility of the views and arguments presented in the text.
objectives.et: * rekonstrueerida tekstis esitatud argumendid ja seisukohad ning hinnata nende veenvust.

learning_outcomes.en:
On successful completion of the course the student:
1. has a solid knowledge of a given text/author's moral philosophy and of what makes it distinctive,
2. is able to critically assess the arguments for and against the views presented in the text,
3. is able to read and understand a non-contemporary text and relate it to contemporary
philosophical concerns,
4. is able to understand and analyze scholarly articles,
5. is able to engage with the issues both in spoken and written form.
learning_outcomes.et:
Kursuse edukalt läbinud üliõpilane:
* omab head ülevaadet käsitletud moraalifilosoofia põhitekstist ning teab, mis on selle teksti iseloomulikud jooned,
* oskab kriitiliselt hinnata argumente tekstis esitatud väidete poolt ja vastu,
* suudab lugeda ja mõista ajaloolist filosoofilist teksti ning suhestada seda tänapäevaste filosoofiliste küsimustega,
* suudab teadusartiklitest aru saada ja neid analüüsida,
* on võimeline avaldama käsitletud teemadel arvamust nii suuliselt kui kirjalikult.

notes.et:
The course will in each different year examine a particular work in moral philosophy that is especially significant in the history of moral philosophy and that continues to be relevant for contemporary debates, whether in normative ethics, metaethics, applied ethics, etc.
Autumn 2024: David Ross, The Right and the Good, 1930.

We will read back to back a rediscovered classic of moral philosophy. In this book the British philosopher David Ross (1877-1971) defended a clear, non-Kantian, deontological alternative to utilitarianism, arguing for the existence of a plurality of basic duties which apply in our lives and which may conflict with each other with no obvious solution. Moreover, as an alternative to simplistic views of value, Ross argues for the existence of a plurality of distinct goods that it is one of our duties to promote - one of them being the moral good of virtue. But Ross also addresses foundational questions about the objectivity of the concepts "right" and "good". The course therefore covers equally what would be normally covered in metaethics and normative ethics classes. Emphasis will be on the close reading and accurate understanding of a text which is now almost 100 years old, as well as on critical re-elaboration of its insights.

description.et:
1. CLASSES AND SEMINARS
Seminar participation is worth 25% of the final grade. Each class (except first and last) is divided into 1h seminar (on the previous week's lecture topics) and 1h lecture (on the next topic). Lectures are meant to provide sufficient background for a comprehension of the texts to be discussed in seminars. Active participation in seminars means coming to the seminar ready to both ask and answer questions about the text given for that seminar, either individually or as part of a small group. Having read the text is a pre-condition for seminar discussion. Having understood it fully or even partly is not. Coming to seminars knowing what you didn't understand is a great start. Successful participation in seminars is also fundamental for successfully completing assignments.
Seminar questions are posted in Moodle as "weekly pre-seminar homework" and need to be answered in Moodle to the best of your ability. Unanswered questions involve a penalty of -1 point in seminar participation score.
Students are allowed to miss not more than 2 compensated seminars. If more than 2 seminars are missed, the student will not pass the course. Each missed UNcompensated seminar incurs a penalty of -5 points on the final score.

2. ASSIGNMENTS
Specific questions set by the lecturer are to be answered, in class, within a given amount of words. The point of the assignments is both to check ongoing understanding and offer possibilities of own critical contribution. A range of questions will be found in Moodle, so you will be able to prepare in advance.
The three assignments are each worth 25% of final grade. (Assignment grades: 1-5: E, 6-10: D, 11-15: C, 16-20: B, 21-25: A)
